awd_titl_txt: Characterizing Bond Activation in Alkanes and Alkyl Halides by Metal and Metal Cluster Cations using Spectroscopy and Photofragment Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-A program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Ricardo Metz and his students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst are studying how alkanes and alkyl halides can be converted to more industrially useful chemicals.  Although natural gas is mostly methane (CH4), it also has up to 6% ethane and 4% propane. Ethane and propane are extremely useful, as they can be converted into ethylene and propylene, which are then used to produce plastics like polyethylene and polypropylene, or other higher value chemicals. Industrially, the production of ethylene and propylene require a great deal of energy and they produce over a pound of carbon dioxide for every pound of ethylene produced. The Metz group uses specialized instruments in which streams of molecules under high vacuum interact with laser light to produce products like ethylene or propylene.   Both graduate and undergraduate students are involved in this research project. In addition to gaining and disseminating knowledge about the chemistry of molecular systems, the students are receiving training in advanced laser techniques and vacuum technologies, as well as computational chemistry, which is used to help interpret the experimental results.  Professor Metz is also helping to introduce eighth-grade girls to research in STEM fields through the Eureka! program.

Complexes of metal ions and metal cluster ions with ethane and propane are produced in a laser ablation/flow reactor source, cooled via supersonic expansion, mass selected in a mass spectrometer and their structure and bonding is characterized using vibrational and electronic spectroscopy. Interaction with the metal weakens the carbon-hydrogen (C-H bonds) in the ethane or propane ligand; this weakening is key to the subsequent catalytic activation of the bond. The experiments measure the extent of C-H bond weakening and polarization by the metal, as they lead to lower frequencies for the corresponding C-H stretch vibrations. These experiments also reveal the identity of reaction intermediates and products in cases where several isomers could be involved, as in competitive C-H and C-C bond insertion. These studies are being carried out for several metals and for clusters with differing numbers of metal atoms to determine the electronic and structural factors that lead to size-dependent reactivity. Complementary velocity map imaging studies of metal halide, sulfide and carbene cation photodissociation measure kinetic energy release and fragment anisotropy, determining accurate bond strengths and probing the couplings between excited electronic states. Photodissociation of a metal halide are also being used to initiate a bimolecular reaction between a metal cation and an alkane, allowing the team to study reaction dynamics with controlled impact parameter and orientation, as a function of translational energy. The broader impacts of this work include potential benefits from improved catalysts as well as training undergraduate and graduate students in mass spectrometry and laser spectroscopy and in broader skills such as problem solving, experimental design, data acquisition and analysis and communication of their results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many important processes in living systems and in the chemical industry rely on catalysts to make critical reactions occur more quickly, to selectively and efficiently produce the desired products, and to run at lower temperatures. In most catalysts, the key reactions take place at transition metals. Understanding how transition metals bind to a molecule, orient it for reaction, then interact with it to form and break covalent bonds is key to understanding why they are such versatile catalysts. Our research studies the non-covalent interactions between transition metal ions and hydrocarbons such as methane and ethane that are the first step in a reaction, as well as the much stronger, covalent bonds between transition metal ions and atoms such as oxygen, sulfur and iodine. Our experimental studies use light in the infrared to determine the structure of complexes in which metals interact with substrate molecules. We also use light in the visible and ultraviolet to measure the strength of covalent bonds involving a metal atom. The experimental results are compared to theoretical predictions in order to determine the accuracy of different theoretical methods and to obtain more information from the experiments.

Despite being abundant and inexpensive, methane is underutilized as a transportation fuel because it is a gas at room temperature, even at extremely high pressures.  This unmet potential has prompted extensive efforts to create catalysts with the ability to efficiently and selectively convert methane to a liquid fuel such as larger hydrocarbons or methanol. Some transition metal cations and cluster ions can carry out this chemistry - reacting sequentially with methane at room temperature to produce larger hydrocarbons. Although they are not practical catalysts, gas-phase metal ions are excellent models as they can be studied in detail using experiment and theory and their reaction patterns can inform the design of practical catalysts. Our experiments study how the number of metal atoms and the number and type of hydrocarbon molecules affects the initial step in activating the C-H bonds in the hydrocarbon for reaction. The experiments were carried out in a mass spectrometer, so clusters with specific composition could be studied, and focused primarily on vanadium as the metal. In each case, the frequency of the C-H stretching vibrations was measured. C-H bonds that interact with metal atom(s) are weakened. This is the key first step to breaking these bonds. Their C-H stretching frequency is related to the strength of the bond, with lower frequencies indicating a weaker bond. Thus, measuring the C-H stretching frequencies provides a convenient tool to measure the extent of bond weakening in a cluster with specific composition. We determined that C-H bonds in ethane are weakened significantly more than in methane and that the first one or two molecules that attach to a metal atom are weakened more than the third or fourth. As for the number of metal atoms, more appears to be better, with those containing four to ten metal atoms weakening bonds in methane more than those with just two or three.

A second series of experiments uses light in the visible or ultraviolet to break a covalent bond, and then measure the velocity with which the two resulting fragments move away from each other. This allows us to measure the strength of covalent bonds involving metal atoms and to study how energy flows in a molecule following absorption of light, forming one set of products rather than another. The strength of the bonds made and broken during a chemical reaction help to determine if the reaction is likely to occur. Calculating bond strengths for molecules that contain transition metal atoms is especially challenging, and these experiments provide a stringent test of competing theoretical methods.
